clinical_study.brief_title: Dose-Response of Adenosine for Perioperative Pain
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Escalating Dose-Response Trial of Intravenous Adenosine for Perioperative Analgesia in Females Undergoing Abdominal Hysterectomy or Myomectomy

brief_summary.textblock: Adenosine A1 and A2 receptors are widely distributed in the brain and spinal cord and represent a non-opiate target for pain management. Activated spinal A1 receptors inhibit sensory transmission by inhibiting the slow ventral root potential, which is the C-fiber-evoked excitatory response associated with nociception. Adenosine may inhibit intrinsic neurons through an increase in K+ conductance and presynaptic inhibition of sensory nerve terminals to inhibit the release of substance P and perhaps glutamate. Although adenosine A3 receptors are not found in the nervous system, adenosine is also known to have anti-inflammatory properties that may contribute to pain relief in the peripheral setting of inflammation.
